What hotel tech leaders say AI will disrupt first… •

external.description:
Insights from 27 leading hotel technology providers show that AI’s impact in 2026 will be fundamentally operational rather than experimental. The consensus is that AI transformation has moved beyond pilots and proofs of concept, as hotels actively invest in the infrastructure that will shape performance for years to come. The most meaningful changes focus on unifying fragmented systems, automating labor-intensive workflows, and enabling predictive, increasingly autonomous decision-making across revenue, operations, and guest engagement. Together, these shifts are creating a widening gap between hotels built on modern, AI-ready platforms and those held back by legacy technology.

Key takeaways

Operational fragmentation is collapsing: AI is unifying data across PMS, POS, labor, revenue, and guest systems, replacing siloed workflows with coordinated decision engines that improve speed, accuracy, and profitability.
Manual processes are giving way to autonomy: Repetitive, staff-intensive tasks across operations, administration, and commercial workflows are increasingly handled by AI-driven automation, freeing teams for higher-value guest and strategic work.
external.title: What hotel tech leaders say AI will disrupt first in 2026

record.text: What Phocuswright’s 2026 predictions mean for hotel operators - AI-led discovery, shifting demand, and new pricing logic will directly reshape hotel performance and distribution

external.description:
"As 2026 unfolds, Phocuswright analysts see travel moving from AI experimentation to operational reality, with direct implications for hotels. Agentic AI, digital identity, and real-time pricing are not abstract trends but forces that will reshape how guests find, evaluate, and book hotels. At the same time, traveler expectations are shifting toward personalization, authenticity, and value optimization under economic pressure. For hoteliers, the next year will be defined by readiness: data quality, distribution strategy, and the ability to adapt to new discovery and booking paths.

Key takeaways

AI becomes the new booking front door: Conversational and autonomous AI tools are increasingly replacing traditional search, meaning hotels must be visible and competitive inside AI-driven discovery and booking flows.
Content quality drives conversion: Hotels with clean, structured rates, availability, policies, and rich content delivered via APIs will perform better as AI agents select and recommend inventory."
external.title: What Phocuswright’s 2026 predictions mean for hotel operators - AI-led discovery, shifting demand, and new pricing logic will directly reshape hotel performance and distribution

record.text: Why Expedia won’t fight ChatGPT’s travel ambitions •

external.description: Expedia is positioning itself to work with AI agents such as ChatGPT rather than trying to block them, reflecting a belief that these automated interfaces will become central to how people discover and book travel. The company sees resistance as potentially making its services invisible to future demand, so it is building backend tools and integrations that allow AI systems to access Expedia’s inventory and complete actions on users’ behalf. This strategic cooperation acknowledges risks, including shifts in revenue models and reduced brand visibility, but aims to ensure Expedia remains relevant as travel discovery becomes increasingly AI-mediated.
external.title: Why Expedia won’t fight ChatGPT’s travel ambitions - Why the travel giant is aligning with AI agents instead of defending traditional booking flows

MPS will continue collaborating with the City of Minneapolis and other partners on emergency preparedness and response.
Sincerely,
Minneapolis Public Schools

external.description: The profile of a cyberstalker (someone who repeatedly uses digital means like social media, email, messaging, GPS tracking, or other online tools to harass, intimidate, monitor, threaten, or obsess over a victim) is not a single stereotype — it varies widely. Research shows cyberstalking differs from traditional (offline) stalking in key ways, including more gender balance among perpetrators, stronger links to certain personality traits, and often greater technological sophistication.  Common Demographic Characteristics Studies consistently show cyberstalkers tend to be:  Younger adults (often in their late teens to 30s, more technologically adept than older traditional stalkers) More educated and digitally skilled compared to offline stalkers Gender distribution — More mixed than traditional stalking:   Many studies show male predominance (around 70% in some samples of known perpetrators)   However, women perpetrate cyberstalking more frequently than in offline cases (sometimes more than men in intimate partner or acquaintance scenarios) Often known to the victim (ex-partner, acquaintance, friend, coworker, or online contact) rather than complete strangers — though stranger cyberstalking does occur  Psychological and Personality Traits Cyberstalkers frequently display elevated levels of certain traits, especially those linked to the Dark Triad / Dark Tetrad (more strongly associated with cyberstalking than traditional stalking):  Psychopathy (especially secondary/impulsive type) — impulsivity, poor self-control, and thrill-seeking Narcissism — entitlement, need for admiration, fragile ego Machiavellianism — manipulative tendencies, strategic exploitation of others Sadism — enjoyment of causing psychological harm  Other common features include:  Low self-control / poor impulse control Attachment issues (e.g., fearful or anxious attachment styles) Jealousy, obsession, entitlement in relationships Lack of empathy toward the victim Higher rates of prior victimization (e.g., physical abuse) or other antisocial behaviors Stress, anxiety, depression (correlated with both perpetration and victimization)  Many cyberstalkers also show higher rates of Internet/social media use, sometimes addictive patterns, and may endorse attitudes that justify stalking (e.g., denial of victim's suffering, viewing control as acceptable).  Typical Motivations The most common drivers include:  Revenge or retaliation (especially after rejection or breakup) Attempt to reconcile or force a relationship Desire to establish control or intimidate Obsession (romantic, sexual, professional, or delusional) Envy, power display, or ideological/financial motives (less common)  Key Behavioral Patterns and Methods Cyberstalkers often use repeated, unwanted contact via:  Email, texts, social media messages Monitoring or hacking accounts GPS/location tracking Impersonation or creating fake profiles Contacting the victim's friends/family Posting embarrassing content (doxing, revenge porn)  Behavior can escalate from seemingly "harmless" monitoring to threats, and it often persists longer than victims expect.  Important Caveats Not all people with these traits become cyberstalkers — most do not. These are risk factors, not guarantees. Cyberstalking is often under-reported and can appear subtle at first (e.g., "just checking in"), making it harder to recognize. Many perpetrators have prior criminal histories (around 25% in some U.S. data), but many do not.  In summary, while the "classic" image might be a rejected ex-partner obsessively monitoring social media, the reality is broader: often tech-savvy, younger individuals (both men and women) driven by control, rejection, or dark personality traits — using the internet's anonymity and accessibility to exert power over others. If you or someone you know is experiencing this, documenting everything and seeking help from law enforcement or support organizations is crucial, as early intervention can make a significant difference.
external.title: What is the profile of a cyberstalker?

record.text: Less than 4 days ago, this same Minister said that child protection and online safety are more important than Irish citizens' human rights. Now he's saying, "Child Sexual Abuse Material what are you going to do, amrite?"

images.alt: Communications Minister Patrick O’Donovan: Photo: True Media

“There are key issues here in terms of freedom of expression, freedom to be able to read or communicate with others without being subject to government licensing, intrusive monitoring and the ability of the State to identify what you’re reading or the websites you visit,” Dr McIntyre said.
“It’s an extraordinarily intrusive proposal. Nothing like this has ever been done in an EU member state, and to my mind it cannot be done legally.”
This weekend, Mr O’Donovan said the Government will bring forward new legislation later this year requiring social media companies to verify the age of users. The system will work in tandem with the Government’s new digital wallet, which will contain a person’s public services card and other state documents that social-media companies can use to verify age. People who refuse to use the new digital wallet would no longer be able to access social-media accounts.
Mr O’Donovan was unbothered by data privacy implications and by the issue of people’s online activity being tracked by the new system.
“There is no other right that trumps the right of a child to be protected, and no amount of convincing me that data protection is more important than child protection is ever going to win out,” he told the Irish Daily Mail.

📢【I Lost My Adventurer's License, but It's Fine Because I Have an Adorable Daughter Now】bekommt eine Anime-Adaption! ✨️

📅 Geplanter Start 》TBA
✨ Genre 》Adventure, Comedy, Fantasy 
🎬 Studio 》TBA

Details im Bildtext 

#AdventurersLicense #BoukenshaRaisensu #AnimeAdaption #LightNovel #Anime #AnimeNews

images.alt:
Die Adventure Fantasy Light Novel »Boukensha Raisensu o Hakudatsu Sareta Ossan da Kedo, Ai Musume ga Dekita node Nonbiri Jinsei o Oka Suru« von Manimani Ononata (Story) und Fuzichoco (Illustrationen) erhält eine Anime-Adaption. Passend dazu wurde ein Teaser Visual und eine glückwunsch Illustration von Fuzichoco zur Ankündigung veröffentlicht. Die Geschichte startete ursprünglich als Webnovel auf Shosetsuka ni Naro. Die Light Novel erscheint seit August 2018 bei GA Novel von SB Creative und umfasst bislang 4 Bände. Die gleichnamige Manga Adaption wird von Fumi Tadaura umgesetzt und läuft seit November 2018 digital bei Manga UP! von Square Enix. Der Manga umfasst bislang 13 Bände. Die Light Novel sowie der Manga sind hierzulande nicht auf Deutsch erhältlich. Weitere Informationen zum Starttermin und zur Produktion sind noch nicht bekannt.

📜 Beschreibung 》
Früher galt Douglas als legendärer Enhancement Spellcaster, doch diese Zeiten sind vorbei. Er wurde aus der Heldengruppe verbannt und verlor schließlich sogar seine Abenteurer Lizenz. Ohne Ziel streift er als Vagabund durchs Land und wirkt wie ein gewöhnlicher, schwacher alter Mann. Als er jedoch auf Rabi trifft, ein kleines Mädchen mit einem Fluch, ändert sich alles. Die Begegnung gibt Douglas eine neue Aufgabe und führt beide auf einen Weg voller Gefahren, Hoffnung und Neuanfänge.

images.alt:
Mit einem neuen Visual und einer Glückwunsch Illustration von raemz zur Anime-Adaption wurde heute der Starttermin für Juli 2026 enthüllt. Außerdem wurde ein Teaser veröffentlicht, in dem der japanische Sprechercast offiziell vorgestellt wurde. Zudem gab man die Mitwirkenden an der Produktion bekannt.

Die Anime-Adaption entsteht bei Studio Makaria, das unter anderem an The Brilliant Healer’s New Life in the Shadows beteiligt war. Regie führt Jo Yoshizaki, während Yuko Kakihara die Series Composition übernimmt, bekannt für Werke wie Cells at Work! und Asobi Asobase. Das Charakterdesign stammt von Yoshihiro Sawada und Yuzuki Ishii, während die Soundumsetzung von Satoshi Motoyama betreut wird, der bereits an Titeln wie Attack on Titan und Psycho-Pass mitgewirkt hat.

🎙️ Charaktere & Cast (Japanisch)
»Kakeru Sorano« von Miyu Irino
»Koharu Fuyutsuki« von Saori Hayami
»Yuko Hayase« von Konomi Kohara
»Ushio Narumi« von Yohei Azakami

📜 Beschreibung 》
An einem Aprilabend in Tokio trifft der introvertierte Student Kakeru Mano auf Koharu Fuyutsuki, eine warmherzige junge Frau, die mit ihrem Lachen sofort auffällt. Erst später erfährt er, dass Koharu blind ist, doch sie lebt trotzdem mutig weiter, geht zur Uni, findet Freunde und träumt sogar davon, eines Tages ein Feuerwerk zu starten. Kakeru beginnt zu begreifen, dass es vielleicht nicht ums Sehen geht, sondern darum, gemeinsam nach vorn zu gehen.

record.text: It's nice that you can create custom instructions for #GitHub #Copilot and limit them to a certain task, i.e. reviews or code generation. But why is the configuration for this negated? Why do I need to exclude the coding task if I want to give instructions for reviews? That's so unintuitive!
An important goal for myself in 2026: write and code regularly "by hand" - without AI. Ideally through a fun side project that I'm doing just for me.
Interesting! I like the idea that everything is a connected object. I'm not sure yet if I like the task management. Need to use it for  few weeks, I think, to form a proper opinion...

I've been using the paid version of GitHub Copilot Pro in VSCode for a while now and it's paid for itself many times over.
I tend to use Claude Sonnet for most tasks and barely reach the token limit. I've been using to create my own MCP servers lately which saves even more time.

Congratulations and happy New year.
Goals are overrated anyway 🤭
Also... those headphones got me through some tough times.

If it works, why not, I started in Perl 29 years ago! 
I heard people are using the current version as well. 😁

I’ve been using the free trial of GitHub Copilot Pro in VSCode for helping me code personal projects and now it’s time to pay. I was considering that vs. Cursor (which we use at work), but Cursor is 2× the price GHCP — and it still has usage limits (which GHCP does not). Am I missing something?

複雑な現実世界の調査ワークフローを多様な課題で実現することを目指しています。

nothings/stb
このリポジトリは、C/C++で使用できる、パブリックドメインまたはMITライセンスのシングルファイルライブラリ集です。
オーディオ処理、画像処理、フォント処理、ユーティリティなど、多様な機能を提供します。
ただし、セキュリティに関する脆弱性が議論される可能性があるため、リスクを許容できない場合は使用を避けるべきです。

record.text:
🤖 People are starting to understand just how resource-intensive #AI is.

Water scarcity is becoming a global issue, we urgently need to cut emissions... while it’s powered by #FossilFuels, can we really justify the use of AI to make fake bobcat videos?! 🤷‍♀️ 

#Sustainability #ClimateChange #GreenSky

images.alt:
Is AI Energy-use and Pollution Worth the Gains?

HOW DO WE REGULATE AGAINST WASTE?

In Ireland, datacenters guzzle 20% of the country’s electricity, while xAI’s Colossus datacenter is spewing more methane than a large power plant.

Meanwhile, xAI’s Grok is generating images of Nazi Mickey Mouse, ChatGPT promotes conspiracies, Google has forced AI results into every search, and Microsoft has embedded Copilot so deeply, you're using AI whether you want to or not.

Considering how resource intensive these machines are, should they be used to find take-out food or create AI slop?

WHAT IF AI COULD COMPENSATE BY REDUCING EMISSIONS IN OTHER PARTS OF THE ECONOMY?

Spain’s Iberdrola says AI has optimized wind turbine maintenance and France’s Engie says it has reduced downtime on solar farms by using AI to detect faults. We could use AI for good – to track deforestation or optimize energy use... but right now we’re mostly using coal-powered datacenters to create clickbait.

🌏 Rare earth materials are essential to manufacture everything from solar panels to smart phones — yet we throw vast amounts of these precious resources into landfill every year.

In 2026, the smartest companies are embedding circularity into their core operations.
#ClimateChange #GreenSky

images.alt:
Do we Need a Circular Economy to Secure Supply Chains?

The circular economy is no longer simply about environmental impact; the geopolitical upheavals in 2025 have exposed the fragility of global supply chains. 

China’s proposals to restrict rare earth exports has forced industries reliant on critical materials to rethink. Maintaining supply chains will require more than simply diversifying suppliers. 

Moving forward, businesses are looking at product take-back programs, advanced recycling, and designing for reuse as ways of securing access to materials, controlling costs, and reducing exposure to geopolitical risk.

[Plus a graphic showing a circular economic model: Take » Make » Use (» Repair or Refurbish) » Collection (» Parts harvesting or Materials recycling) » Residual waste.]

record.text: 🎧 The future is speaking — are you listening? Discover why voice and audio will define 2026. Read more: https://www.pollinger.ai/blog/why-audio-and-voice-will-be-a-big-deal-in-2026

external.description:
For years, AI progress has been framed around typing from a keyboard and using screens. Think of a typical day spent hopping between chat windows, documents, dashboards, and tabs, asking questions, copying answers, and pasting them somewhere else. Chat interfaces, prompts, dashboards, documents. Useful and powerful, but still very visual and very manual.

That is about to change.

By the end of 2026, audio and voice will become one of the most important ways people interact with AI, especially for small businesses and professionals who value speed, accessibility, and context over clever prompts.

This is not about smart speakers making a comeback. It is about AI becoming something you talk to, listen to, and work alongside, rather than something you sit down and type at.

## From novelty to control layer

A useful signal of where this is heading comes from recent developments around Google’s Gemini on Android. Gemini is beginning to gain deeper system-level control, and will allow users to trigger actions across apps using natural voice commands, not just ask questions.

That shift matters.

Once voice can reliably control your device, not just respond to queries, it becomes an interface layer rather than a feature. At that point, typing starts to feel slow and clunky by comparison.

This mirrors what happened with touchscreens. Early smartphones still relied heavily on keyboards. Then touch became good enough, and behaviour changed almost overnight.

Voice is now approaching a similar tipping point.

## Designed for real life, not desks

One reason audio will accelerate in 2026 is simple: it fits real life better.

Small business owners do not spend their days neatly at desks. They are driving, walking between meetings, preparing for pitches, reviewing notes, juggling admin, or doing client work.

Voice allows AI to slot into those moments.

Imagine a consultant finishing a client meeting, walking to the next one, and speaking a quick voice note that AI turns into action points, follow-up emails, and reminders before they even sit down again.

Here are practical voice input ideas you can start using today:

  * Dictating ideas while walking, then having them summarised into structured notes

  * Talking through a problem and receiving spoken suggestions or prompts

  * Listening to daily briefings rather than reading dashboards

  * Capturing meeting reflections immediately after a call, while context is fresh




By 2026, these behaviours will feel normal rather than experimental.

## Less friction means more use

The biggest barrier to AI adoption is not cost or capability. It is friction.

Typing prompts, refining wording, switching tabs, and formatting outputs all add mental overhead. Audio strips much of that away.

Speaking is faster than typing. Listening is often reminded as easier than reading when you are tired or overloaded. Reducing effort leads to more frequent use, which in turn leads to better outcomes.

This matters particularly for non-technical users. Voice lowers the confidence barrier. You do not need to know how to prompt well to explain something out loud.

You just talk, pause, then talk again.

## Rethinking the idea of prompts

One subtle but important shift that audio brings is conversational flow.

Typed prompts tend to encourage concise, transactional interactions. Voice encourages context, correction, interruption, and clarification. Paradoxically, that often produces better AI output.

When people speak, they naturally share background, priorities, constraints, examples, and tone cues. All the things that help AI respond in a more useful way.

Later this year, the idea of carefully crafted prompts may feel unnecessary for many everyday tasks. Instead, AI will become better at extracting intent from natural speech and follow-up questions.

A simple way to test this now is to brainstorm out loud with AI, explaining your thinking as you go, rather than trying to compress it into a perfect typed prompt.

## Turning speech into content

This naturally builds on the reduction in friction described above. Speed and ease translate directly into tangible business outputs.

From a marketing and communications perspective, audio opens up new ground.

Short spoken updates can quickly become blog drafts, LinkedIn posts, email newsletters, podcast snippets, or training materials.

Voice-first workflows suit people who think better out loud than on a keyboard. Many business owners fall squarely into that category.

There is also a trust factor. Voice feels human. Hearing tone, pacing, and emphasis creates a stronger connection than text alone.

That helps explain why voice notes, podcasts, and short audio clips are popular and continue to perform well on messaging and social platforms, even when video dominates attention.

## Accessibility is central, not optional

Audio is also an accessibility multiplier.

For people with visual impairments, dyslexia, fatigue, or neurodivergent working styles, voice can make AI genuinely usable rather than theoretically available.

As expectations around digital accessibility continue to rise, voice-enabled systems will stop being nice to have and start being expected.

Convenience plays a role here too. With tools like Microsoft Copilot, you can listen to meeting summaries in Teams or hear document and podcast-style summaries directly in OneDrive without opening files or staring at another screen. That ability to absorb information while walking, travelling, or between tasks makes audio far more than an accessibility feature.

It is also worth noting that both ChatGPT and Microsoft Copilot already offer the option to read all responses out loud, which is useful not just for accessibility but for comprehension and focus.

Have you tried listening to an AI response instead of reading it?

## The technology is catching up

Hardware matters here too.

Improved microphones, on-device processing, better noise cancellation, and lower latency are making voice interactions feel far more natural. Combined with the increasing popularity of earbuds and headphones, in-car audio systems, and let's not forget the potential explosion of audio capable smart glasses and wearables, AI is no longer tied to a laptop or desk.

AI is present and available when you need it, but not demanding constant attention.

That is a very different relationship from staring at a screen.

## What this means for small businesses

For small businesses, audio and voice will not replace text. They will sit alongside it as a faster, more human layer.

Practical steps to consider now include:

  * Using voice input for notes, ideas, and reflections

  * Experimenting with spoken briefings instead of written summaries

  * Identifying where audio could remove friction from everyday workflows

  * Watching how platform-level voice control evolves, especially on mobile




Those who become comfortable talking to AI now will be better placed when voice becomes the default in many contexts.

## Looking ahead

In my recent article on AI trends for small businesses, I explored how interfaces are shifting. Audio and voice are a key part of that story.

By 2026, the question will not be Can I talk to AI, but Why would I type this?

The businesses that adapt early will save time, think more clearly, and work in ways that feel closer to how humans naturally operate.

And that is usually where lasting change happens.

A useful question to ask now is this: where could voice and audio remove friction from your own working day in 2026, even if you start with just one small habit?
external.title: Why Audio and Voice Will Be a Big Deal in 2026

CT Planet Fitness operator pays $2M to resolve COVID loan allegations

https://www.vitaminrush.com/285213/ct-planet-fitness-operator-pays-2m-to-resolve-covid-loan-allegations/

The Connecticut-based fitness company that owns and operates more than 130 Planet Fitness centers around North America …

external.description: The Connecticut-based fitness company that owns and operates more than 130 Planet Fitness centers around North America has paid more than $2 million to resolve allegations that it received a COVID relief loan intended for small businesses. The agreement was announced Wednesday in a statement issued by the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the District of Connecticut. According to federal officials, IFH Holdings Group, Inc., doing business as IGNITE Fitness Holdings, applied in February 2021 for a “second-draw” Paycheck Protection Program loan for $2 million. IGNITE owns and operates more than 130 Planet Fitness locations in the United States and Canada
external.title: CT Planet Fitness operator pays $2M to resolve COVID loan allegations

The company said the launch reflects existing user behavior, noting that more than 230 million people ask health-related questions on ChatGPT each week. The Health experience separates medical and wellness conversations from general chats, while prompting users to move into the Health section when sensitive topics arise. ChatGPT Health is designed to retain relevant personal context, such as fitness goals, and can integrate data from wellness platforms including Apple Health, Function, and MyFitnessPal. OpenAI stated
